Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of Arabic vocabulary and grammar.  I particularly improved my speaking skills (through class discussions and tests, which were always oral) and writing skills (through writing assignments and the final project).  I also learned more about Arab-speaking cultures.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Ustaadha Sarab is amazing!  She is so kind, patient, and thoughtful.  Another strength of the course is its focus on speaking: I improved so much.

I think the homework load could be adjusted.  We always had much more homework than we had time to go over in class, which meant I didn't learn as much from it as I could have.  I think a combination of reducing the homework load a little and providing answer keys to students after homework is turned in would help.  

Also, I think more frequent reading and writing assignments might be a good idea.  I'm looking ahead to ARBC 150, and there is going to be a big step up in the amount and frequency of reading and writing.  Since it takes a while to build reading and writing skills in Arabic, it might be good to do more of that than is in Al Kitaab or the storybooks.  

Lastly, I would have liked a greater focus on grammar (and case endings), including more explanations and activities in class.  Arabic grammar is so complicated, and it can be hard to learn on your own from a textbook.  Plus, I felt like sometimes I learned concepts for an assignment but never really had the chance to use them in my speaking and writing, and I'm thinking ahead to future classes that will teach grammar even less and assume that you know it.  That being said, I really appreciated that tests weren't just fill-in-the-blank grammar quizzes -- they were much more accurate to how you use language in real life.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of breakout rooms was really great to practice language in small groups!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would, especially with Ustaadha Sarab!  I would tell students considering the course that it is a bigger time commitment than I realized at first, because you have conversation meetings with TAs for the beginning of the semester and you complete 2 hours a week of one-on-one Natakallam meetings in April.  Plus, I signed up for CLS language tutoring (would recommend!) which adds another hour a week.  I wasn't really aware of how the time commitment would increase in the last month of class, which made scheduling a little difficult, so that is one thing to know.  But it's a great class with a great professor, and Arabic is a wonderful and rewarding language.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lecture; TA section; office hours and Peer tutor hours
